bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Edward Tucker, 1717 September 16

div1.p: Robert Carter to Weymouth, England, merchant Edward Tucker, September 16, 1717, reporting a bill of exchange he has drawn to Thomas Black, and the terrible storm that severely damaged the crops. He advises Tucker to send Captain Giles Russell on the Brimpton because there will be tobacco to be shipped.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Edward Tucker, September 16, 1717
div1.p:
The cheif reason of this is to advise you of a
Bill I drew on you a few days agon to Thos. Blak
for six pounds, eight shill & six pence which I
desire you to pay.

I have alreadie acquainted you wth the storm w=
ee had on 24th of last month wch hath don
a great deal of damage to or. Corn & Tobo and
hath bin genl thro' the country— Yet
believe if you send Capt. [Giles] Russel he will
find Tobo enough, tho there is a mighty
cry amongst us.
div1.closer: I am, Sir, your humble servant

div1.head: Notes
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Minor-Blackford Papers, James Monroe Law Office and Museum, Fredericksburg, Virginia. These texts are all nineteenth-century copies. Apparently there was in existence a letter book of Robert Carter's—now lost—from which the unknown copiest recorded these texts. As they are the only texts, the punctuation and "corrections" obviously supplied by the copiest have been retained. The copist used rows of the letter "x" to indicate material that he did not copy from the letter book.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The return address, county, and state have been added for clarity to this unheaded letter.

[1] Captain Giles Russell commanded the Brimpton, a vessel which sailed often from Weymouth to Virginia from at least as early as 1711. (Survey Report 9711, Survey reports, Virginia Colonial Records Project.)
